case_vignette: A man, aged 68 years, with no known history of atopy presents with a 4-month history of an itchy and burning rash on the legs that has been recurring every winter for the past 3 years. He notes that he had dry skin at baseline and did not use emollients, but he did try hydrocortisone 1% cream without improvement. Examination revealed ovoid, erythematous, well-marginated plaques on the lower legs and dorsal feet with variable scaling and focal weeping and crusting. There were no nail changes, and the rest of his skin examination was notable only for xerosis.
question: What is the final diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have an itchy and burning rash on my legs that recurs every winter.
How long has this been happening?
It has been happening for the past 3 years.
Does the rash improve when the weather becomes warmer?
Yes, the rash recurs every winter.
Do you notice any triggers or activities that seem to worsen the rash?
No, I haven't noticed any specific triggers or activities that worsen the rash.
Do you have any history of allergies or asthma?
No, I do not have any known history of allergies or asthma.
Have you received any treatment or used any medications for this rash in the past? If yes, what were they and were they effective?
Yes, I tried using hydrocortisone 1% cream, but it did not improve the rash.
Have you noted any changes in the appearance or spread of the rash over the years?
No, the appearance and spread of the rash have been consistent each year.
Final Diagnosis: Eczema (Winter Eczema or Seasonal Dermatitis)

trial_0.summarized_conversation: A patient reports having an itchy and burning rash on their legs that recurs every winter for the past three years. The patient confirms that the rash recurs every winter but has not noticed any specific triggers or activities that worsen the condition. The patient does not have any known history of allergies or asthma. The patient has attempted treatment using hydrocortisone 1% cream, however, this did not improve the rash. Additionally, the appearance and spread of the rash have been consistent each year.
trial_0.summarized_frq: Winter eczema (also known as asteatotic eczema or eczema craquelé)
